history.content:
Highly discourage taking 162, 126, 170 together, even any subset of size 2 of these classes. They’re all very important and dense. It is imperative to absorb the material to do well. Taking more than 1 together inhibits that. However, given your track record, you may be able to do two. In that case, taking (126 OR 170) AND 162 may work since you get a pset class and a project class to balance. Don’t know much about 137A. But do keep in mind that adding additional techs to taking 2 of these behemoth classes together will prove difficult still.

---
That sounds incredibly, incredibly difficult. I'm not too familiar with physics 137a but I *think* (from what I remember from my physics friend) that it's one of the harder upper divs, and probably comparable to 170 in workload/difficulty. If that's true, I don't think this courseload is possible. If you're fast at psets and *very* good at math, I think 126/170/137a might be doable, but 162 is very high workload from what I've heard. Maybe swap out 162 for 188? But honestly I feel 126/170/137a alone will be more than enough.

---

I can speak to 162 and 126 - even those two as your only techs will be a beating. I have heard that 137A is one of the lighter physics upper divs (but I have no experience with it); if you were to switch 162 out for something lighter it might be doable.

Highly discourage taking 162, 126, 170 together, even any subset of size 2 of these classes. They’re all very important and dense. It is imperative to absorb the material to do well. Taking more than 1 together inhibits that. However, given your track record, you may be able to do two. In that case, taking (126 OR 170) AND 162 may work since you get a pset class and a project class to balance. Don’t know much about 137A. But do keep in mind that adding additional techs to taking 2 of these behemoth classes together will prove difficult still.

children.subject:
DS major here who took a lot of upper division physics. Physics 137a is definitely the "easier" of the other upper div physics courses and is a nice intro into upper division physics. With a good probability foundation I would say it gets easier. The more math you know (special functions, PDEs, stuff from math 121b, etc.), the easier it gets. The second half of the course I would say is harder than the first, but not by much.

Depending on the professor, you'll get weekly/biweekly problem sets and the class will range in exam difficulty. The class is definitely doable, but I'm unsure with the amount of techs you're doing. Let me know if you have any specific questions about the course.
It's really different to take an upper, especially the notoriously hard ones, i.e. 126 170 162

61b 16b (with sahai hh) 126 + 2 breadths here and almost died

When you look at course load, you should really look at the peak combined load in a week or so, not the avg

I would say on avg my workload was actually fine, but there were 1-2 weeks when it was just really difficult

For reference, this past semester I took CS61A, math 105, math 185, and physics 105 (plus 4 units of 12-15 hrs per week URAP). I had a positive outcome grade-wise, but I was basically extremely stressed 100% of the time and it seriously took a toll. Can’t speak to upper div CS but I imagine the workload is similar if not more intense (162 I’ve heard is particularly hard).

history.content:
I’m debating whether taking that courseload is going to kill me next semester. For context, i am currently taking 61b, ee16b, physics 5c, and physics 5cl and doing perfectly fine. 

I’ve gotten an A in cs70, cs61a, and ee16a, and anticipate to get the A/A- in cs61b, ee16b. But this upcoming courseload is going to be a whole different world. 

I’m not sure. Opinions? If i were to change something, i would switch 162 out for something, but i’m not sure what. I want to have a lighter upperdiv cs course that actually interests me.
history.subject: Eecs126 + Cs170 + cs162 + physics137a
